meta_id: Add a unique number for each row
Country_code: The A2 (ISO) country codes for the country where the sensor is installed: https://www.worldatlas.com/aatlas/ctycodes.htm) (e.g. SE for Sweden)
Experiment_name: Name for a set of sensors belonging together. For ease of processing, submit different experiments in different folders
Experimental_manipulation: Vegetation manipulation (growth chambers, disturbance, management treatments, etc.): yes, Purely observational: no
Experiment_insitu: In situ monitoring or experiments: yes, Experiments in pots, ecotrons, mesocosms: no
Experiment_climate: Was any climate variable manipulated (e.g. temperature, precipitation, wind ... )? Any set-up that artificially changes microclimate from surrounding conditions (e.g. also vegetation removal) should answer 'Yes'
Experiment_citizens: Was the sensor installed by citizens?
Experiment_design: Description of the experimental design in long text (e.g. methods section), all info needed to understand the design
Experiment_doi:
If data or project are published, provide the main URL relevant for the data (e.g. of the dataset if it got a separate DOI from the paper).

If the project has no DOI yet, a link to a project website could be provided.
Site_id: Name of the plot where the logger is installed. Note that coordinates are provided at the logger level (column R and S). For recurring submissions: please keep location codes for the same location constant over time!
Elevation: Elevation of the site (in meter above sea level) when available. For most applications, we will use DEM-derived and standardized elevation values, but it is practical for a quick look to have user-provided elevation values.
Habitat_type: Habitat defined following https://www.iucnredlist.org/resources/habitat-classification-scheme. See last sheet for the list of habitat types. A rough habitat classification (at least e.g. forest vs open terrain) is VERY IMPORTANT for the usefulness of sensor data!
Site_comments: Providing more information on the vegetation (e.g., vegetation height) and soil (e.g., bulk density) at your site is HIGHLY recommended! This can be done in the 'vegetation metadata'-file
Logger_code: Serial number and/or nickname of the logger
Raw_data_identifier:
a name that matches EXACTLY with the name given to the raw data files. Preferably, the LOGGER CODE.
o When several sensors measure in parallel at one location (e.g. for TMS-loggers), data for each logger can then be submitted as 4 columns with the same LOGGER CODE, with columns labelled with the SENSOR CODE (e.g. T1, T2, T3 and Soil Moisture according to the TMS-definition). This is the example given here.
Latitude: Decimal_degrees. The exact latitude and longitudeof the logger location (either WGS84, in decimal degrees, with a minus for southern/western hemisphere, or with your local coordinate system)
Longitude: Decimal_degrees. The exact latitude and longitude of the logger location (either WGS84, in decimal degrees, with a minus for southern/western hemisphere, or with your local coordinate system)
EPSG: The EPSG-code of the measurement location. Defaults to 4326 for WGS84, which is the one per default used by GPSses, Google Maps, etc.
GPS_accuracy: Spatial resolution of the location measurement in meters
Logger_serial_number: Serial number of the logger. Ideally, this is the same as the 'Logger_code' column, but if you don't have the serial number, you leave this column empty, and give your logger another unique code (e.g. the plotcode)
Logger_age: Year of first utilisation of the sensors (or approximation)
Sensor_code: (e.g. identifier of specific sensors on the logger, this code should match a column name in "Raw time series data")
Sensor_shielding: Is a radiation shield in place for that specific sensor (e.g., top shield of TOMST TMS4 only valid for air temp sensor)?
Sensor_shielding_type:
Homemade: Yes
Company-provided: No
No shield: NA
Unit: Important, especially for soil moisture measurements!
Sensor_accuracy: In the sensor unit, company-provided accuracy, if known
Sensor_height: Centimeter above/below the soil surface (negative values for soil temp, positive values for measurements above the soil surface; for sensors spanning a range of heights, take average, and fill out sensor length in the next column).
Sensor_length: Length of sensors measuring across a range of depths (e.g. TMS moisture sensor)
Start_date_year: The first and last full day of in-situ temperature measurements, with a separate column for year, month and day (to reduce date-time errors).
Licence:
Creative Commons license for your data. Open Acces: CC0, Open Acces with credit to the authors CC-BY, access after validation by the authors C) - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creative_Commons_license

If in doubt, choose CC-BY
Species_composition: Is species comp. data available: Yes/No
Species_trait: Is species trait data available: Yes/No

meta_id: Each line in this metadata-file represents one TIME SERIES, as measured by one SENSOR.
One sensor can result in multiple time series (e.g., if it gets redeployed elsewhere).
A LOGGER is a device holding multiple SENSORS, such as the TOMST TMS4 with its 4 sensors (3 temperature + 1 soil moisture).
A SITE is a specific location (with associated latitude and longitude) where a measurement is done (e.g. a plot).
An EXPERIMENT is a cohesive group of sites, following the same protocol or otherwise belonging together.
